title: Fi (Dominant) confirmation
intro: Answer based on your long-term life pattern. Use 4–5 only when it is consistently true across your life. If you choose 4–5, you can optionally tick real-life examples to confirm the pattern.

items.text: My feelings and personal values strongly shape my preferences, attachments, and decisions (it’s hard to ignore them).
examples: Even if something is efficient, I avoid it if it feels wrong to me.
I can’t fully commit to a choice unless it feels personally right.
I often know what I like/dislike quickly, without needing external opinions.
I struggle to do something that conflicts with my values, even under pressure.
When I betray my own values, I feel guilt or self-disrespect strongly.
My mood and inner state noticeably influence what I want to do that day.
I have strong personal tastes (music, aesthetics, people) that feel identity-linked.
I would rather be true to myself than be approved by everyone.

items.text: Living with integrity is extremely important to me; I care about authenticity and honoring each person’s unique experience.
examples: I dislike being pressured to pretend or perform a fake version of myself.
I get upset when people dismiss someone’s feelings as “not logical enough.”
I dislike environments that feel cold, soulless, or purely status-driven.
I feel strongly about respecting personal boundaries and individuality.
I speak up (or withdraw) when something feels morally wrong to me.
I care more about meaning than about appearances.
I’m sensitive to hypocrisy (saying one thing, doing another).
I want my actions to match my beliefs, not just my words.

items.text: I am usually aware of how I feel, and I want space to process or express it (often creatively or privately).
examples: I notice subtle shifts in my mood and what caused them.
I need time alone to understand what I really feel.
I express feelings through art, music, writing, style, or personal projects.
I dislike being forced to explain feelings before I’m ready.
I prefer deep, honest emotion over shallow positivity.
I feel uncomfortable when others treat emotions as ‘noise’ to remove.
I sometimes feel emotions intensely and need time to stabilize.
I value having a private inner world that is not easily shared.

items.text: When I feel low, I can become withdrawn/alienated and need alone time to settle emotionally before I can function well again.
examples: When upset, I can’t just ‘push through’—I need time to reset inside.
I become quiet when I’m hurt, and talking too early makes it worse.
If I feel misunderstood, I may isolate and replay the situation internally.
I can lose motivation if my emotional needs are ignored.
I need emotional clarity before being productive again.
I dislike being told to “stop being sensitive” when I’m struggling.
I feel better after processing feelings privately (sleep, journaling, walking).
I dislike social demands when I’m emotionally drained.

items.text: I strongly dislike people who feel inauthentic, intrusive, disrespectful, or emotionally cold/impersonal.
examples: I dislike controlling people who ignore others’ boundaries.
I get irritated by fake politeness used to manipulate.
I dislike nosy behavior that pries into personal life without respect.
I distrust people who act moral in public but cruel in private.
I dislike domineering ‘my way or the highway’ attitudes.
I avoid people who treat others like objects or tools.
I dislike environments where empathy is mocked or punished.
I prefer sincere people over socially polished people.

items.text: I often receive feedback that I’m sensitive or hard to persuade when my values are involved (and I may appear stubborn or self-righteous).
examples: People say I take things personally.
I’m sensitive to being called selfish, weak, or irrational.
When something violates my values, I don’t ‘compromise easily.’
I can seem moralizing when I care strongly about an issue.
I can be quiet or uncommunicative when I feel judged.
People say I’m hard to reason with if they ignore what I feel is right.
I can become moody when I feel disrespected.
I prefer staying true to myself over winning an argument.

items.text: I have a weak sense of identity and weak attachments; my values feel fuzzy or easily changeable.
examples: I often don’t know what I truly like until others choose first.
My preferences change mainly due to social influence.
I rarely feel strongly attached to people, places, or personal meaning.
I can adopt values from others without inner conflict.
I feel ‘blank’ when asked what matters most to me.
I can drop relationships or interests easily with little emotional impact.
I don’t relate to strong personal tastes or identity-linked preferences.
I usually don’t feel internal conviction about what is right for me.

items.text: I can function fine even when unhappy; feelings don’t strongly affect my productivity or decisions.
examples: Even if I’m miserable, I still perform normally without much slowdown.
I can ignore personal feelings to meet goals with little internal cost.
My decisions are mostly unaffected by mood or personal meaning.
I rarely need alone time to process emotions.
I believe feelings should not matter much for important decisions.
I can stay neutral and effective even in emotionally uncomfortable situations.
I quickly move on from emotional events without deep processing.
I don’t relate to emotional intensity influencing my whole day.

items.text: I feel wary of emotional intensity and usually need to justify strong feelings/opinions logically before I accept them.
examples: Strong feelings make me suspicious; I prefer to ‘verify’ them.
I avoid emotional topics because they feel messy or biased.
I get uncomfortable when people express intense emotion.
I usually explain opinions with reasons, not with personal conviction.
I dislike “I feel it’s right” as a justification.
I prefer calm objectivity over emotional authenticity.
I downplay feelings because I don’t trust them.
I think feelings are unreliable compared to facts.

items.text: I have poor emotional awareness; I often believe feelings are biased/unreliable and I don’t track my inner state much.
examples: I often don’t know what I feel until much later.
People say I seem emotionally disconnected or hard to read.
I struggle to name emotions precisely.
I treat emotions as interruptions rather than information.
I’m not very affected by personal meaning or sentimental value.
I rarely reflect on feelings unless something extreme happens.
I prefer to focus on external tasks rather than inner alignment.
I don’t relate to having a rich inner emotional landscape.
